text:
UKinbound CEO urges Chancellor to acknowledge significance of national tourism boards Published on : Monday, October 26, 2015
Speculations are rife about the expenditure cuts on non-protected departments such as the department for culture, media and sport during this year’s Comprehensive Spending Review in the Autumn Statement in the United Kingdom.
Comprehensive Spending Review is a governmental process in the United Kingdom carried out by HM Treasury to set firm expenditure limits and, through public service agreements, define the key improvements that the public can expect from these resources.
The move could see drastic cuts for the UK’s national tourism boards, VisitEngland and VisitBritain.
The chief executive of UKinbound, Deirdre Wells, in a letter to the Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, has urged the latter to acknowledge the importance of the national tourism boards and the role they play within the British tourism industry.
UKinbound is a trade association founded in 1977 to represent the interests of the UK’s inbound tourism businesses.
“VisitBritain and VisitEngland are recognised universally as having done an enormous amount to deliver the step change in visitor numbers to the UK which we have seen in recent years,” Deirdre Wells wrote to George Osborne.
The letter further stated: “Every extra visitor who comes to the UK brings an additional £630 in export earnings and contributes £216 to the Exchequer; therefore supporting VisitBritain and VisitEngland in growing this industry further is sensible economics.”
“However, both organisations suffered cuts in the previous Spending Round which resulted in core activity, such as business support and the overseas network being reduced dramatically. There is a real concern within the industry that a further cut in this Spending Round – to an already modest budget – will have a serious impact on vital services.”
